Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates by stating that "no cities in the South had guaranteed paid sick days" one year ago, when in fact there were cities in the South that had adopted such policies.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide specific evidence or data to back up the statement that no cities in the South had guaranteed paid sick days one year ago.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes a problematic assumption by not clearly defining what is considered part of the "American South" and whether states like Maryland and Washington D.C. should be included.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation to the claim, as it is mentioned that Maryland and Washington D.C. had already adopted paid sick leave policies before Austin did in early 2018, indicating that there were cities in the South with such policies.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there were cities in the South, like Maryland and Washington D.C., that had adopted paid sick leave policies before Austin did in early 2018.
Understate: The claim understates the presence of guaranteed paid sick days in the South by stating that no cities had such policies, when there were actually cities in the South that had already implemented them.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not clearly defining the scope of the "American South" and not providing enough evidence to support the statement.
